description.narrative: The Capacity for Disaster Reduction Initiative (CADRI Partnership) is a UN Joint Programme that supports 15 countries over the period 2019-2023 to reduce vulnerability to disaster and climate risk across socio-economic sectors.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Indicator 1) Number of countries who have adopted more comprehensive and integrated multi-sectoral plans and systems to reduce vulnerability to disaster and climate change risk across socio-economic sectors with a focus on the most vulnerable groups.
Indicator 2) Tools, methodology and delivery mechanisms are developed to bolster the capacity of the UN System to address multi-dimensional risk factors and provide an integrated offer of expertise to support countries assess and prioritize their investment in DRR & CCA across socio-economic sectors.

comment.narrative:
Notwithstanding the fact that the degree of ownership and the culture of risk reduction may vary significantly between regions and between countries, countries are facing similar challenges in reducing disaster and climate change risk :
1. Low prioritization of DRR and CCA in national and local strategies and budgets 2. Fragmentation which prevents synergies between sectors and actors 3. Inadequate design and planning of capacity development interventions which are piecemeal, short term and not well sequenced.

Targets for output 1.1: One multi-stakeholders risk information “platform” supported in at least one region; Digital functionalities for diagnosis of country risk information system developed including participatory mapping of user needs; E-catalogue of CADRI Partners risk information training modules and tools.
Targets for output 2.1: Four (4) country capacity diagnosis; Four (4) country DRR/CCA planning frameworks; CADRI tool digital functionalities developed and tool rolled out at country level after second testing; Three to Five (3 to 5) regional webinar trainings on the tool (English language AP & ESA; French language WCA; Russian & Spanish depending on funding availability for translation)
Target for output 2.2: Mapping and analytical inventory of CADRI Partners DRR & CCA training modules across sectors.
Targets for output 2.3: Three (3) country capacity diagnosis of preparedness systems, plans and specialized training; Multi-sectoral government led After Action Review / Lessons learnt methodology applied to public health emergency (COVID-19); Multi-sectoral After Action Review methodology applied to other hazards. At least one (1) country pilot.
Targets for output 3.1: Two (2) UNCT DRR Frameworks integrating DRR and CCA with conflict and gender sensitivity lens; Two (2) UNCTs supported in resource mobilization.
Targets for outputs 3.2: At least one (1) UN emergency preparedness framework (multi sectoral contingency plan or AAR)
Targets for output 4.1: CADRI Tool marketing & launch strategy implemented; CADRI tool launch at two global events organized; Four country stories / Medium stories
Targets for output 4.2: Regionalization sustainability scenario.
Targets for output 4.3: Client feedback mechanisms used; Country annual impact study produced as part of M&E Plan; Mid Term Review preparatory work completed; Board resource mobilization strategy.

Country Results:
Senegal: - Capacity diagnosis of a numbers of socio-economic sectors: agriculture and food security; nutrition; health; environment; infrastructure and land use planning, water and sanitation, social protection and mining.
Togo: - CADRI Capacity diagnosis was validated and the government prioritized 85 actions to implement which serve as the foundation for the national DRR strategy 2020-2030. - CADRI Partnership facilitated training for the personnel of the newly established Agence Nationale de la Protection Civile.
Mauritius: - The National Policy, Strategic Framework, and Action Plan 2020-2030 were officially published. These documents leverage greatly on the findings and recommendations of the CADRI capacity diagnosis report. - CADRI piloted the hiring of an expert to help the government jump start implementation of some of the recommendations.
Bolivia: - CADRI capacity diagnosis was validated by the Government. - The recommendations will be considered as inputs in the process of formulation of the new cooperation framework between the Government and the UN System.
Kyrgyz Republic: - CADRI Partnership conducted a virtual interagency scoping mission.
Madagascar: - CADRI Partnership conducted a scoping mission.
Zambia: - CADRI Partnership conducted a scoping mission.
The CADRI tool: - (Re)design of the CADRI Tool digital functionalities; - Finalization of the sector modules; - A series of introductory webinars on the CADRI Tool was organized in six regions in June-November 2021; - The webinars was attended by more than 200 experts from more than 20 organizations.
M&E: - The CADRI Partnership conducted and disseminated its first Impact Study in Namibia; - The CADRI client survey was rolled out in Mauritius and Bolivia.

Target 1 - Country Results: At least 4 country frameworks (Comoros, Togo, Mauritius, Bolivia) At least 2 UNCT DRR frameworks (Iran & Lao) At least 4 Capacity Diagnosis(Lao, Cameroon, Botswana, Kyrgyzstan) At least 4 new country requests Target 2 - CADRI Tool development: CADRI assessment and planning tool rolled out at country level Risk information service line developed Post Disaster After Action Review methodology developed Target 3 - Resource Mobilization & Partnership building: Resource mobilization strategy finalized EU experts deployment mechanism streamlined Expertise in risk financing and infrastructure mobilized JPO & SBP positions Target 4 - CADRI Partnership strengthening: At least 2 agencies upgrade to Executive Partner status At least 2 country engagements jointly with GFDRR CADRI Secretariat effectively staffed by Executive Partners All seven regional facilitation mechanisms have clear SOP Revised engagement criteria and streamlined country request process

M&E: - Launch of PAG M&E Survey - CADRI Partners co-designed a monitoring and evaluation (M&E) plan to regularly assess the uptake of CADRI capacity development recommendations by the government and UN country teams, and the quality and relevance of the services delivered jointly by the agencies. - As part of the developed M&E plan, a client feedback survey was rolled out in Comoros, Iran, Mauritius, and Togo
CADRI Tool: - The CADRI tool content was updated in 2020 to deepen analysis of the legal and policy framework on preparedness, the methodologies and technical skills, and the equipment and technologies required for preparedness and early warning, including digital solutions - CADRI digital tool testing with 18 CADRI experts from 8 organizations
CADRI companion guides: - CADRI developed two guides ‘(The Scoping guide’ and the ‘Prioritization and Planning Guide’) to support regional agencies, government, and UN country teams in delivering CADRI capacity development services at the country level.
Country Results:
Iran: - UN Programming mission. - The CADRI partnership made technical contributions to the finalization of the national DRR strategy. - CADRI consolidated six compendia of good practices to respond to issues raised by the Government.
Togo: - Technical validation of the capacity diagnosis report and recommendations - Mapping of UN country team DRR mapping
Kyrgyz Republic: - Mapping of UN country team DRR programming. - CADRI developed, in close collaboration with the Ministry of Emergency Situations, a Scoping Guide and Questionnaire in Russian
Senegal: - Capacity diagnosis, including interviews with 37 institutions - 46 experts, covering the West and Central African region, were trained on the CADRI methodology to facilitate the national capacity diagnosis for the Republic of Senegal.
Namibia: - The Government, through a Cabinet decision, has endorsed six CADRI recommendations for implementation
Mauritius: - Mauritius Capacity diagnosis recommendations endorsed by Cabinet

Target 1) One (1) country per region has benefitted from integrated offer of expertise in DRR / CCA across sectors Target 2) CADRI assessment and planning sectoral tools are revised to reflect the changing capacity development needs and demands (CC/DRR integration, private sector, conflict sensitivity, gender and age sensitivity) Target 3) The CADRI Partnership Secretariat has increased implementation capacity to respond to more country requests Target 4) The CADRI Partnership has enhanced its internal and external communication through increased visibility in global events and impactful communication products

Target 1) One country in each of the seven regions benefited from CADRI support Report on progress: Achieved. The CADRI Partnership expertise has served six regions and six countries to plan capacity development interventions across a wide range of sectors: West, Southern and Eastern Africa (Comoros, Mauritius, Togo), to Latin America (Bolivia), to Asia Pacific (Lao PDR), to Middle East (Jordan). In the ECIS region, the engagement in Kirgizstan has been postponed to early February 2020 at the Government request. This has resulted into four capacity diagnosis (Bolivia, Comoros, Mauritius, Togo), one contextualized methodology for capacity diagnosis (Lao PDR), and two draft UN DRR programmatic frameworks (Jordan and Bolivia).
Target 2) CADRI sector tools are revised to reflect the changing capacity development needs and demands Report on progress: Not achieved. The CADRI assessment and planning tool structure, including a revised analytical framework of capacities, as well as the tool web interface functionalities, have been developed to reflect the changing nature of capacity development needs: more focus on CC-DRR integration, private sector capacities, conflict sensitivity, LNOB / HRBA and gender and age sensitivity. This entailed an analytical mapping of 85 existing DRR/CC assessment tools, as well as a consultative process involving 15 CADRI Partners through two face-to-face retreats and three webinars. Concurrently a contract tendering was concluded for the development of the web based tool interface. Despite significant investment in analytical thinking, the development of the questionnaire was delayed due to unforeseen events leading to the unavailability of the lead Climate Change consultant for six weeks. The draft tool questionnaire (generic and sectoral) is expected to be ready by 31st March 2020.
Target 3) The CADRI Partnership Secretariat has increased implementation capacity to respond to more country requests Report on progress: Achieved. The CADRI Partnership has implemented a strategy to expand its internal delivery capacity in three ways: i) Strengthening the CADRI Secretariat back-office function through the mobilization of a Junior consultant and an Administrative and Finance consultant. The Junior consultant was recruited for two-months on a trial period, then extended for one-year and an agreement was negotiated with IOM to retain his services in the long term. The identification Administrative and Finance consultant was only finalized in December after the first recruitment process initiated in May was unsuccessful. The strengthening of the back-office has led to significant improvements in the implementation of the procurement plan and the communication / reporting work flows. ii) Building an expanded CADRI Secretariat team through tapping into the specialized expertise of CADRI Executive Partner agencies to contribute to the implementation of the CADRI 2019 AWP. A standing bi-weekly CADRI Secretariat meeting invitation was extended to FAO, IOM, UNICEF, UNFPA technical experts to contribute to the preparation of country engagement and regionalization. Team building is an on-going process that culminated with the preparation of the CADRI Secretariat Retreat on 2020 work planning. iii) Strengthening CADRI implementation capacity in the regions through on-the-job training, and mobilization of regional consultants. UNDP, IOM/FAO and UNDRR were trained on leading scoping missions and capacity diagnosis. Four recruitments of regional consultants were initiated in WCA, LAC, SEA and ECIS regions and two consultants received induction to their new role. Finally the CADRI regional coordination mechanisms became more operational through regular planning meetings (WCA, ESA, ECIS, MENA, AP) and one regional refresher was organized for the AP region. The regionalization process is work in progress that will continue throughout 2020 until a Mid Term Review can properly assess the impact of regionalization.
Target 4) The CADRI Partnership has enhanced its internal and external communication through increased visibility in global events and impactful communication products Report on Progress: Achieved The CADRI Partnership achieved good visibility in global events. During the Global Platform on DRR, CADRI hosted and organized a well-attended dialogue and Ignite Stage as well as 16 bilateral consultations with Government delegations. At the Humanitarian Partnership Week, CADRI hosted and facilitated a dialogue on innovation in preparedness, as well as a donor briefing on the new Joint Programme. Additionally throughout 2019 the CADRI Secretariat issued regular quarterly bulletins, developed 3 country stories, updated the website content, developed a social media strategy, set up a photo library and developed a new visual identity for the CADRI Joint Programme.

Targets for output 1.1: One multi-stakeholders risk information “platform” supported in at least one region: Costa Rica risk information system with UNDRR
Targets for output 2.1: Four (4) Capacity Diagnosis (Madagascar, Kyrgyz Republic, Zambia, Uzbekistan, Mozambique, Cameroon); Three (3) national DRR strategies (Bolivia, Senegal, Maldives, Tanzania); Digital tool trial & enhancements Modules: energy, social protection & tourism; 5 regional webinars (at least 150 experts trained); ToT on team leader role in the tool (at least 10 experts trained.
Targets for output 2.2: Learning offer Developed: Risk informed planning, preparedness.
Targets for output 2.3: Multi-sectoral government led After Action Review / Lessons learnt methodology applied to public health emergency (COVID-19); Multi-sectoral After Action Review methodology applied to other hazards.
Targets for output 3.1: At least 3 UNCT frameworks (Timor, Madagascar, Haiti).
Targets for output 4.1: Digital tool marketing: launch at GP and HPNW, launch in five regions; Website, social media, communication outreach; Regionalization; Finalization of the Mid term review; Annual Impact Studies (Jordan & Zimbawe); Funding proposals developed for 5 donors (Germany, Sweden, EU-ECHO, Norway, Switzerland).
